documentationChunks.content: The HubspotMarketingApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-hubspot` to connect to users' HubspotMarketingApi accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you will need to configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.

The HubspotCrmApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-hubspot` to connect to users' HubspotCrmApi accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you will need to configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.

## Auth

<Callout type="info">
The HubspotUsersApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-hubspot` to connect to users' HubSpot accounts. To use the MCP Server, configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.
</Callout>

**Configuration:**
- Add an auth provider with id `arcade-hubspot` in your platform.
- Provide the OAuth credentials and required scopes for HubSpot access.
- Ensure redirect URIs and network access to HubSpot endpoints match your deployment (especially for self-hosted installations).

**Notes:**
- Verify permissions granted by the auth provider cover the user data the MCP Server needs.
- For cloud or managed deployments, consult your platform docs for provider setup specifics.

## Auth

<Callout type="warning">
The HubspotMeetingsApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-hubspot` to connect to users' Hubspot accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you must configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.
</Callout>

**Configuration summary:**
- Configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider in your Auth Providers settings.
- Provide the HubSpot application credentials and required callback/redirect information to the auth provider.
- Enable the provider for any users or teams that need access to HubspotMeetingsApi functionality.

**Important:**
- The MCP Server cannot connect to HubSpot on behalf of users unless the `arcade-hubspot` provider is present and correctly configured.

At this time, Arcade does not offer a default Salesforce Auth Provider. To use
  Salesforce auth and MCP Sever, you must create a custom Auth Provider with your
  own Salesforce OAuth 2.0 credentials as documented in [Salesforce Auth
  Provider](/references/auth-providers/salesforce).

## Install and Run the Arcade Engine

<Callout type="warning">
At this time, you must **self-host the Arcade Engine** to use the Salesforce MCP Server. Arcade Cloud does not support Salesforce auth.
</Callout>

- Self-host the Arcade Engine: [self-host](/references/auth-providers/salesforce)
- Follow the step-by-step instructions in the [Salesforce Auth Provider](/references/auth-providers/salesforce) page.
documentationChunks.header: ## Install and Run the Arcade Engine

documentationChunks.content:
## Self-hosting the Arcade Engine with Salesforce Auth

<Callout type="info">
Arcade Cloud does not support Salesforce auth. To use the Salesforce MCP Server or develop custom Salesforce tools, you must self-host the Arcade Engine.
</Callout>

**Configuration steps:**
- Self-host the Arcade Engine: [configure the Arcade Engine](/guides/deployment-hosting/configure-engine)
- Configure the Salesforce auth provider in your engine configuration: [Salesforce Auth Provider](/references/auth-providers/salesforce)

<Callout type="info">
Follow the linked guides for detailed setup and engine configuration.
</Callout>

In order to use the MCP Server, you will need to configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.

<Callout type="warning">

The HubspotCmsApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-hubspot` to connect to users' HubspotCmsApi accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you will need to configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.

The Arcade Cloud Platform offers a default [Hubspot auth provider](/references/auth-providers/hubspot). If you use it, there's nothing to configure. Your users will see `Arcade` as the name of the application requesting permission.

## Auth

<Callout type="info">
The HubspotEventsApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-hubspot` to connect to users' HubspotEventsApi accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you must configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.
</Callout>

## Auth

<Callout type="info">
The HubspotAutomationApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-hubspot` to connect to users' HubSpot accounts. To use the MCP Server, you must configure the `arcade-hubspot` auth provider.
</Callout>

**Configuration guidance:**
- Configure an auth provider with id `arcade-hubspot` in your platform.
- Provide the required HubSpot OAuth credentials (for example, client ID and client secret) and set the correct callback/redirect URL in your auth provider settings.
- Ensure your deployment (self-hosted or cloud) can reach HubSpot's OAuth endpoints and that client secrets are stored securely.

**Notes & important limitations:**
- This integration requires OAuth-based authentication and a properly configured auth provider.
- On self-hosted deployments, verify network egress to HubSpot and any firewall or proxy settings that may block OAuth traffic.

The Arcade Walmart Search MCP Server uses the [SerpAPI](https://serpapi.com/) to get product information from Walmart.

- **Secret:**
  - `SERP_API_KEY`: Your SerpAPI API key.

<Callout type="info">
Setting the `SERP_API_KEY` secret is only required if you are [self-hosting](/guides/deployment-hosting/configure-engine) Arcade. If you're using Arcade Cloud, the secret is already set for you. To manage your secrets, go to the [Secrets page](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard/auth/secrets) in the Arcade Dashboard.
</Callout>

The Arcade Google Search MCP server uses the [SerpAPI](https://serpapi.com/) to get results from a Google search.
- **Secret:**
  - `SERP_API_KEY`: Your SerpAPI API key.

<Callout type="info">
Setting the `SERP_API_KEY` secret is only required if you are [self-hosting](/guides/deployment-hosting/configure-engine) Arcade. If you're using Arcade Cloud, the secret is already set for you. To manage your secrets, go to the [Secrets page](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard/auth/secrets) in the Arcade Dashboard.
</Callout>

## Default parameters

Language, Country, Distance Unit, and Travel Mode are configurable through environment variables. When set, they will be used as default for Google Maps tools.

Providing a different value as `language`, `country`, `distance_unit`, or `travel_mode` argument in a tool call will override the default value.

**Language**

The language code is a 2-character code that determines the language in which the API will search and return directions. There are two environment variables:

- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`: a default value for all Google tools. If not set, defaults to 'en' (English).
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_MAPS_LANGUAGE`: a default value for the Google Maps tools. If not set, defaults to `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`.

A list of supported language codes can be found [here](#languagecodes).

**Country**

The country code is a 2-character code that determines the country in which the API will search for directions:

- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_MAPS_COUNTRY`: a default value for the Google Maps tools. If not set, defaults to `None`.

A list of supported country codes can be found [here](#countrycodes).

**Distance Unit**

The distance unit is a string that determines the unit of distance to use in the Google Maps search:

- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_MAPS_DISTANCE_UNIT`: a default value for the Google Maps tools. If not set, defaults to `GoogleMapsDistanceUnit.KM`.

A list of supported distance units can be found [here](#googlemapsdistanceunit).

**Travel Mode**

The travel mode is a string that determines the mode of travel to use in the Google Maps search:

- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_MAPS_TRAVEL_MODE`: a default value for the Google Maps tools. If not set, defaults to `GoogleMapsTravelMode.BEST`.

A list of supported travel modes can be found [here](#googlemapstravelmode).

- **Secret:**
  - `SERP_API_KEY`: Your SerpAPI API key.
    <Callout type="info">
      Setting the `SERP_API_KEY` secret is only required if you are
      [self-hosting](/guides/deployment-hosting/configure-engine) Arcade. If you're
      using Arcade Cloud, the secret is already set for you. To manage your
      secrets, go to the [Secrets
      page](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard/auth/secrets) in the Arcade
      Dashboard.
    </Callout>

Language and Country are configurable through environment variables. When set, they will be used as defaults for Google News tools.

Providing a different value as `language_code` or `country_code` argument in the tool call will override the default value.

**Language**

- The language code is a 2-character code that determines the language in which the API will search and return news articles.
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`: a default value for all Google search tools. If not set, defaults to `en` (English).
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_NEWS_LANGUAGE`: a default value for the news search tools. If not set, defaults to `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`.

A list of supported language codes can be found [here](#languagecodes).

**Country**

- The country code is a 2-character code that determines the country in which the API will search for news articles.
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_NEWS_COUNTRY`: a default value for the `SearchNews` tool. If not set, defaults to `None` (search news globally).

A list of supported country codes can be found [here](#countrycodes).

The Arcade YouTube Search MCP Server uses the [SerpAPI](https://serpapi.com/) to get video information from YouTube.
- **Secret:**
  - `SERP_API_KEY`: Your SerpAPI API key.

<Callout type="info">
Setting the `SERP_API_KEY` secret is only required if you are [self-hosting](/guides/deployment-hosting/configure-engine) Arcade. If you're using Arcade Cloud, the secret is already set for you. To manage your secrets, go to the [Secrets page](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard/auth/secrets) in the Arcade Dashboard.
</Callout>

Language and Country are configurable through environment variables. When set, they will be used as defaults for YouTube tools.

Providing a different value as `language_code` or `country_code` argument in a tool call will override the default value set in the environment variables.

**Language**

The language code is a 2-character code that determines the language in which the API will search and return video information. There are two environment variables:

- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`: a default value for all Google Search tools. If not set, defaults to `en` (English).
- `ARCADE_YOUTUBE_SEARCH_LANGUAGE`: a default value for the YouTube Search tools. If not set, defaults to `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`.

A list of supported language codes can be found [here](#languagecodes).

**Country**

The country code is a 2-character code that determines the country in which the API will search for videos:

- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_COUNTRY`: a default value for all Google Search tools. If not set, defaults to `None`.
- `ARCADE_YOUTUBE_SEARCH_COUNTRY`: a default value for the YouTube Search tools. If not set, defaults to `ARCADE_GOOGLE_COUNTRY`. If `ARCADE_GOOGLE_COUNTRY` is not set, the default country for YouTube tools will be `us` (United States).

A list of supported country codes can be found [here](#countrycodes).

The Arcade Google Shopping Search MCP Server uses the [SerpAPI](https://serpapi.com/) to get product information from Google Shopping.

- **Secret:**
  - `SERP_API_KEY`: Your SerpAPI API key.

  <Callout type='info'>
  Setting the `SERP_API_KEY` secret is only required if you are [self-hosting](/guides/deployment-hosting/configure-engine) Arcade. If you're using Arcade Cloud, the secret is already set for you. To manage your secrets, go to the [Secrets page](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard/auth/secrets) in the Arcade Dashboard.
  </Callout>

Language and Country are configurable through environment variables. When set, they will be used as defaults for Google Search tools. Providing a different value as `language_code` or `country_code` argument in a tool call will override the default value set in the environment variables.

**Language**

- The language code is a 2-character code that determines the language in which the API will search and return information.
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`: a default value for all Google Search tools. If not set, defaults to `en` (English).
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_SHOPPING_LANGUAGE`: a default value for the Google Shopping Search tools. If not set, defaults to `ARCADE_GOOGLE_LANGUAGE`.

A list of supported language codes can be found in the LanguageCodes section.

**Country**

- The country code is a 2-character code that determines the country in which the API will search.
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_COUNTRY`: a default value for all Google Search tools. If not set, defaults to `None`.
- `ARCADE_GOOGLE_SHOPPING_COUNTRY`: a default value for the Google Shopping Search tools. If not set, defaults to `ARCADE_GOOGLE_COUNTRY`. If `ARCADE_GOOGLE_COUNTRY` is not set, the default country for Google Shopping tools will be `us` (United States).

A list of supported country codes can be found in the CountryCodes section.

The Microsoft Teams MCP Server requires a Microsoft 365 account. Personal Microsoft accounts are not supported.

## Auth

<Callout type="info">
The Arcade Reddit MCP Server uses the [Reddit auth provider](/references/auth-providers/reddit) to connect to users' Reddit accounts.
</Callout>

The Arcade Trello API MCP Server requires two environment variables to authenticate with the Trello API:

- `TRELLO_API_KEY`
- `TRELLO_API_TOKEN`

**How to obtain your credentials:**

1. Log in to your [Trello account](https://trello.com/)
2. Navigate to the [Power-Ups Admin Portal](https://trello.com/power-ups/admin)
3. Click on "New" to create a new Power-Up or select an existing one
4. In your Power-Up settings, go to the **API Key** tab
5. Your **API Key** will be displayed
6. Click on the "Token" link to generate a **Token** (this will require authorization)
7. Authorize the token with the required scopes
8. Copy both the API Key and Token for use in your configuration

<Callout type="warning">
Keep `TRELLO_API_KEY` and `TRELLO_API_TOKEN` secret. Do not commit these values to source control. Use a secure secret manager or environment configuration for provisioning production credentials, and grant the token only the minimum scopes required for your integration.
</Callout>

<Callout type="info">
You can directly access your API key at: [Trello App Key](https://trello.com/app-key)
</Callout>

For more details, see the [Trello API Authentication documentation](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/trello/guides/rest-api/authorization/).
**Warning**: Do not commit Twilio API keys, API key secrets, or phone numbers to source control. Store credentials securely and restrict access to production secrets.

## Features

- Send SMS messages via Twilio
- Send WhatsApp messages via Twilio
- Built for Arcade integration

## Prerequisites

<Callout type="info">
You need an active Twilio account and appropriate messaging access. For WhatsApp functionality, WhatsApp must be enabled on your Twilio number.
</Callout>

- Twilio Account SID
- Twilio API Key SID
- Twilio API Key Secret
- A Twilio phone number
- WhatsApp enabled on your Twilio number (for WhatsApp functionality)

For details on creating API keys, see [Create an API Key](https://www.twilio.com/docs/iam/api-keys#create-an-api-key).

## Configuration

By default the configuration is loaded from an `engine.env` file in your project root. You can specify a different file if needed.

<Callout type="warning">
Do not commit environment files that contain secrets. Use a secrets manager or environment-specific secure storage for production credentials.
</Callout>

Ensure the environment file or secret store contains the following variables:

- `TWILIO_ACCOUNT_SID`
- `TWILIO_API_KEY_SID`
- `TWILIO_API_KEY_SECRET`
- `TWILIO_PHONE_NUMBER`
- `MY_PHONE_NUMBER`

- Confirm the runtime environment reads the chosen env file or secret source before initializing the Twilio client.

## Usage Examples

- Send an SMS to a personal number with a short message.
- Dispatch a WhatsApp message to a recipient with content such as lists or quotes.
- Schedule a reminder SMS to be sent at a future time.
- Share a motivational quote via WhatsApp.
- Provide a weather update via SMS for a specified location.
- Send birthday or greeting messages via WhatsApp or SMS.

These examples illustrate typical use cases; ensure recipients have consented to receive messages and that messaging complies with applicable regulations and Twilio account permissions.
The SharePoint MCP Server requires a Microsoft 365 account. Personal Microsoft accounts are not supported.

<Callout type="info">
The TicktickApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-ticktick` to connect to users' TickTick accounts.
</Callout>

In order to use the MCP Server, you will need to configure the `arcade-ticktick` auth provider.

Learn how to configure the TickTick auth provider in the [TickTick auth provider documentation](/references/auth-providers/ticktick).

The Arcade Outlook Mail MCP Server uses the [Microsoft auth provider](/references/auth-providers/microsoft) to connect to users' Microsoft accounts.

<Callout type="info">
Use the [Microsoft auth provider](/references/auth-providers/microsoft) to configure OAuth for Outlook Mail. See the provider page for setup instructions and the permissions required to access users' mailboxes.
</Callout>

## Auth

<Callout type="info">
The Arcade Outlook Calendar MCP Server uses the [Microsoft auth provider](/references/auth-providers/microsoft) to connect to users' Microsoft accounts.
</Callout>

subPages.content:
Arcade securely connects your AI agents to APIs, data, code, and other systems via Tools. The Arcade integration for Slack lets Arcade's tools interact with your Slack workspace to help your team work more efficiently.

You can use the Arcade Slack app in the Arcade Dashboard Playground or integrate it into your own applications. The app itself does not directly expose an LLM  you will typically use Arcade's tools together with an LLM when building workflows.

What the Arcade app for Slack can do:

- Send messages to Slack channels and direct messages on your behalf
- Find information in channels and direct messages
- Generate content, summaries, and responses for messages you receive
- And more  see the Slack MCP Server documentation for details on available tools and required scopes

Permissions and scopes:

- Common capabilities involve sending and reading messages and accessing channel/conversation content
- For a complete permission summary and the exact scopes required by each tool, see the [Slack MCP Server documentation](/resources/integrations/social-communication/slack)

Install and get started:

- Install the Arcade app for Slack from the Arcade Dashboard by clicking the Add to Slack flow.
- Invite Arcade to any channel or direct message by typing `/invite @Arcade` so it can read and interact with content in that channel.
- Use Arcade's Slack tools to send messages, find information in conversations, and generate summaries of discussions.
- You can try features in the Arcade Playground by chatting with an LLM or executing Slack tools directly from the dashboard.

Next steps for production:

- For production or branded usage, create your own Slack application to customize permissions, branding, and app behavior: [create your own app for Slack](/references/auth-providers/slack).

Need help?

- Check our [Slack MCP Server documentation](/resources/integrations/social-communication/slack)
- [Contact our support team](/resources/contact-us)

**Note**: The Arcade app for Slack requires an active Arcade account. If you don't have one yet, [sign up for free](/signup).

You'll need to be a workspace admin or have permission to install apps to add Arcade to your Slack workspace.

When using LLMs with Slack, responses may sometimes contain inaccuracies. Always review AI-generated content before taking action.

You'll need to be a workspace admin or have permission to install apps to add Arcade to your Slack workspace.
When using LLMs with Slack, responses may sometimes contain inaccuracies. Always review AI-generated content before taking action.

subPages.content:
## Environment Variables

<Callout type="info">
These environment variables control Slack toolkit behavior for concurrency and pagination. Set them as numeric strings (see each variable for specific requirements).
</Callout>

- `SLACK_MAX_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS`

  Controls the maximum number of concurrent requests to Slack API in any tool execution. The value must be a numeric string representing an integer greater than or equal to 1.

  **Default:** `3`

- `MAX_PAGINATION_SIZE_LIMIT`

  Controls the maximum number of items requested in a single call to a Slack API endpoint. Some Slack tools allow requesting a larger number of items per call, but the tool will paginate results internally while respecting this limit.

  **Default:** `200` (Slack supports, but discourages a limit larger than 200)

- `MAX_PAGINATION_TIMEOUT_SECONDS`

  Controls the maximum number of seconds any given Slack tool should wait while paginating responses from the Slack API.

  **Default:** `30` (expressed in seconds)

<Callout type="warning">
Ensure these values are set as numeric strings. High concurrency or large pagination sizes can increase the risk of hitting Slack rate limitstune values according to your Slack plan and observed rate-limit behavior.
</Callout>

documentationChunks.content:
## Authentication

The Arcade Luma API MCP Server requires one environment variable to authenticate with the [Luma API](https://docs.luma.com/reference/getting-started-with-your-api):

- `LUMA_API_KEY`

**How to obtain your credentials:**

1. Navigate to your [Luma dashboard](https://lu.ma/)
2. Click on your profile icon and go to **Settings**
3. Navigate to **API** or **Developer Settings**
4. Click **Generate API Key** or **Create New Key**
5. Copy the API key and store it securely

<Callout type="warning">
  The Luma API requires a **Luma Plus** subscription. Be careful with your API
  key since it provides full access to your Luma account.
</Callout>

For more details, see the [Luma API Getting Started guide](https://docs.luma.com/reference/getting-started-with-your-api).
The Arcade Zoom MCP Server uses the [Zoom auth provider](/references/auth-providers/zoom) to connect to users' Zoom accounts.

subPages.content:
**Note**: The Arcade Zoom app requires an active Arcade account. If you don't have one yet, [sign up for free](/signup).

**Warning**: You'll need a Zoom account with appropriate permissions to allow Arcade to access your Zoom data.

Arcade securely connects your AI agents to Zoom. The Arcade Zoom app lets Arcade-based tools interact with your Zoom account to help manage meetings and gather information more efficiently.

You can use this app in the Arcade Dashboard Playground or integrate it into your own applications.

- List your upcoming meetings within the next 24 hours
- Retrieve meeting invitation details for specific meetings
- Find the participants and/or registrants for a specific meeting
- And more

For details on available scopes and integration, see the [Zoom integration documentation](/resources/integrations/social-communication/zoom).

<Callout type="warning">
When using LLMs with Zoom, responses may sometimes contain inaccuracies. Always review AI-generated content before taking action.
</Callout>

## Support and troubleshooting

If you encounter issues connecting Arcade to your Zoom account:

- Verify you've granted all required permissions during authorization
- Ensure your Zoom account is active and in good standing
- Use a compatible browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge)
- Clear your browser cache and cookies, then try again

### Adding the Arcade Zoom app to your Zoom account

If connecting via the Arcade Playground did not work, add the Arcade Zoom app to your Zoom account using the "Connect with Zoom" button in the Arcade Dashboard.

### Authorize the requested permissions

When connecting Arcade to your Zoom account, you'll be asked to authorize specific permissions depending on which features you use:

- **user:read:user** - Allows Arcade to access basic profile information
- **user:read:email** - Enables Arcade to access your email address
- **meeting:read:meetings** - Enables Arcade to list your upcoming meetings
- **meeting:read:invitation** - Enables Arcade to read meeting invitation details

These permissions ensure Arcade can perform necessary functions while protecting your privacy and security.

### Removing the Arcade Zoom app

To remove the Arcade Zoom app from your Zoom account, go to the [Zoom App Marketplace](https://marketplace.zoom.us/user/installed) and uninstall the app.

Arcade only stores authentication tokens, not your Zoom data. These tokens become invalid when you uninstall the app and will eventually expire. To remove tokens immediately, delete the Zoom Auth Provider from the [Arcade Dashboard](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard/auth/oauth).

## Privacy and security

- We only request the minimum permissions needed for our tools to function
- Your Zoom credentials are never stored on our servers
- All communication between Arcade and Zoom is encrypted
- You can revoke Arcade's access to your Zoom account at any time through your [Zoom App Marketplace](https://marketplace.zoom.us/user/installed)

## Next steps

Consider [creating your own Zoom app](/references/auth-providers/zoom) for branding and customized permissions.

## Need help?

- Check our [Zoom integration documentation](/resources/integrations/social-communication/zoom)
- [Contact our support team](/resources/contact-us)

documentationChunks.content:
## Configuring Discord auth

- Create a Discord Application in the [Discord developer portal](https://discord.com/developers/applications).
- In the OAuth2 settings for your Discord app, set the redirect URI to the redirect URL generated by Arcade.
- Copy the Client ID and Client Secret from your Discord app (you may need to reset the secret to see it).

### Add the Discord app to Arcade

- Open the OAuth section of the Arcade Dashboard and click **Add OAuth Provider**.
- Select **Discord** as the provider.
- Choose a unique **ID** for your provider (for example, `my-discord-provider`) and add an optional **Description**.
- Enter the **Client ID** and **Client Secret** you obtained from the Discord developer portal.
- Ensure the **Redirect URL** shown by Arcade is added to your Discord app's OAuth2 redirect URIs.
- Click **Save**.

<Callout type="warning">
Make sure the redirect URI configured in your Discord app exactly matches the Redirect URL generated by Arcade. If they do not match, the OAuth flow will fail.
</Callout>

<Callout type="info">
You may need to reset your Discord app's Client Secret to view it. Store the secret securely; you will not be able to view the same secret value again in the Discord developer portal.
</Callout>

When you use features that require Discord authentication with your Arcade account, Arcade will automatically use the configured Discord OAuth provider.

Use the Discord auth provider in your agents and AI apps to obtain a user token for calling the Discord API. See [authorizing agents with Arcade](/get-started/about-arcade) for the overall authorization model.

- The authorization flow creates an authorization challenge that the end user completes in their browser.
- Typical OAuth scopes include `identify`, `email`, `guilds`, and `guilds.join` depending on the API access your app requires.

<Callout type="info">
The authorization process requires the user to complete the OAuth challenge (often in a browser). Ensure your application guides users to complete that step so the token issuance can finish.
</Callout>
documentationChunks.header: ## Using Discord auth in app code

documentationChunks.content:
You can build custom tools that interact with the Discord API and require a user's Discord authorization.

- Mark a tool as requiring Discord authorization so that the tool runtime obtains a user token for API calls.
- The runtime populates the tool execution context with the user's Discord token (accessible via `context.authorization.token`).
- Request only the OAuth scopes your tool needs (for example, `guilds` to list servers or `guilds.join` to add a user to a guild).

<Callout type="info">
The token provided in the execution context is a user OAuth token. Use it to call Discord API endpoints on behalf of the authorized user and respect Discord's developer policies and the user's privacy.
</Callout>

The MailchimpMarketingApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-mailchimp` to connect to users' MailchimpMarketingApi accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you will need to configure the `arcade-mailchimp` auth provider.

The Mailchimp OAuth provider enables secure authentication with Mailchimp's Marketing API using OAuth 2.0. This allows your tools and agents to access user data and perform actions on their behalf. For detailed information on setting up the OAuth provider, including how to register your application with Mailchimp and configure the auth provider in Arcade, see the [Mailchimp Auth Provider documentation](/references/auth-providers/mailchimp).

<Callout type="info">
Ensure you register your application with Mailchimp and configure the required redirect URIs. Use the auth provider id `arcade-mailchimp` when configuring the MCP Server.
</Callout>

## GoogleSlides Reference

Below is a reference of enumerations used by some tools in the GoogleSlides MCP Server:

### OrderBy

- **CREATED_TIME**: `createdTime`
- **CREATED_TIME_DESC**: `createdTime desc`
- **FOLDER**: `folder`
- **FOLDER_DESC**: `folder desc`
- **MODIFIED_BY_ME_TIME**: `modifiedByMeTime`
- **MODIFIED_BY_ME_TIME_DESC**: `modifiedByMeTime desc`
- **MODIFIED_TIME**: `modifiedTime`
- **MODIFIED_TIME_DESC**: `modifiedTime desc`
- **NAME**: `name`
- **NAME_DESC**: `name desc`
- **NAME_NATURAL**: `name_natural`
- **NAME_NATURAL_DESC**: `name_natural desc`
- **QUOTA_BYTES_USED**: `quotaBytesUsed`
- **QUOTA_BYTES_USED_DESC**: `quotaBytesUsed desc`
- **RECENCY**: `recency`
- **RECENCY_DESC**: `recency desc`
- **SHARED_WITH_ME_TIME**: `sharedWithMeTime`
- **SHARED_WITH_ME_TIME_DESC**: `sharedWithMeTime desc`
- **STARRED**: `starred`
- **STARRED_DESC**: `starred desc`
- **VIEWED_BY_ME_TIME**: `viewedByMeTime`
- **VIEWED_BY_ME_TIME_DESC**: `viewedByMeTime desc`

This Toolkit is not available in Arcade Cloud. You can use these tools with a
  [self-hosted](/guides/deployment-hosting/configure-engine) instance of Arcade.

<Callout type="info">
Google Docs supports hierarchical tabs within documents. Tabs can be nested up to 3 levels deep and include metadata with approximate character and word counts.
</Callout>

**Tool support:**
- `GetDocumentMetadata` returns hierarchical tab structures with approximate character and word counts for each tab
- `GetDocumentAsDocMD` and `SearchAndRetrieveDocuments` include all tab content in their output
- `GetDocumentAsDocMD` supports filtering to retrieve content from a specific tab using the `tab_id` parameter

**Tab structure:**
- Each tab has a unique `tabId`, `title`, `index`, and `nestingLevel`
- Tabs can be nested up to 3 levels deep (parent  child  grandchild)
- Tab metadata includes approximate character and word counts for each tab's content
The Arcade Docs MCP Server uses the [Google auth provider](/references/auth-providers/google) to connect to users' Google accounts.

## 
  Handling multiple Atlassian Clouds

A Jira user may have multiple Atlassian Clouds authorized via the same OAuth grant. In such cases, the Jira tools must be called with the `atlassian_cloud_id` argument. The [`Jira.GetAvailableAtlassianClouds`](/resources/integrations/productivity/jira#jiragetavailableatlassianclouds) tool can be used to get the available Atlassian Clouds and their IDs.

When a tool call does not receive a value for `atlassian_cloud_id` and the user only has a single Atlassian Cloud authorized, the tool will use that. Otherwise, an error will be raised. The error will contain an additional content listing the available Atlassian Clouds and their IDs.

Your AI Agent or AI-powered chat application can use the tool referenced above (or the exception's additional content) to guide the user into selecting the correct Atlassian Cloud.

When the user selects an Atlassian Cloud, it may be appropriate to keep this information in the LLM's context window for subsequent tool calls, avoiding the need to ask the user multiple times.

**_It is the job of the AI Agent or chat application to:_**

1. Make it clear to the chat's end user which Atlassian Cloud is being used at any moment, to avoid, for example, having a Jira Issue being created in the wrong Atlassian Cloud;
1. Appropriately instruct the LLM and keep the relevant information in its context window, enabling it to correctly call the Jira tools, **especially in multi-turn conversations**.

subPages.content:
### `JIRA_MAX_CONCURRENT_REQUESTS`

Arcade uses asynchronous calls to request Jira API endpoints. In some tools, multiple concurrent HTTP requests may be made to speed up execution. This environment variable controls the maximum number of concurrent requests to Jira API in any tool execution.

The value must be a numeric string with an integer greater than or equal to 1.

**Default:** `3`

### `JIRA_API_REQUEST_TIMEOUT`

Controls the maximum number of seconds to wait for a response from the Jira API. This is also applied, in some cases, as a global max timeout for multiple requests that are made in a single tool execution. For instance, when a tool needs to paginate results from a given endpoint, this timeout may apply to the entire pagination process in total, not only to the individual requests.

The value must be a numeric string with an integer greater than or equal to 1.

**Default:** `30`

### `JIRA_CACHE_MAX_ITEMS`

<Callout type="info">
  The caching strategy does not involve caching Jira API responses that go into tool output, but only internal values.
</Callout>

The Arcade Jira MCP Server will cache some values that are repeatedly used in tool execution to enable better performance. This environment variable controls the maximum number of items to hold in each cache.

The value must be a numeric string with an integer greater than or equal to 1.

**Default:** `5000`

## Auth

The Arcade Gmail MCP Server uses the [Google auth provider](/references/auth-providers/google) to connect to users' Google accounts.

<Callout type="warning">
**Important**: Gmail access requires Google OAuth and specific scopes to read, modify, or send messages. Ensure your OAuth client is configured in the Google Cloud Console and the required scopes are approved for your project.
</Callout>

<Callout type="info">
Self-hosted deployments must configure a valid OAuth consent screen and provide the correct redirect URIs. Cloud-hosted instances may use the built-in provider configuration.
</Callout>

**Permission summary:**
- `https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.readonly`  read messages and metadata
- `https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.modify`  read and modify (archive, label, delete)
- `https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.send`  send messages on behalf of the user
- Additional scopes may be required for mailbox settings or full admin access

**Setup notes / important limitations:**
- Ensure the OAuth consent screen and scopes are accepted by Google; some scopes require verification.
- For enterprise use, coordinate with Google Workspace admins to allow app access and domain-wide delegation if needed.
- Avoid requesting broader scopes than necessary to reduce approval friction and security risk.

**Critical**: Confluence Cloud requires OAuth 2.0 (3LO) or API tokens; Confluence Server/Data Center (self-hosted) commonly uses Basic auth, OAuth 1.0a, or app links. Ensure you select the correct auth provider for your deployment. See [Confluence auth](/references/auth-providers/confluence)

Confluence is available in two main deployment models with important differences to consider:

- **Confluence Cloud**
  - Uses Atlassian's hosted API endpoints and OAuth 2.0 (3LO) or API tokens.
  - Atlassian-managed rate limits and feature rollout; some admin capabilities are restricted to site admins.
- **Confluence Server / Data Center (self-hosted)**
  - Hosts live on customer infrastructure; may expose different API paths and authentication options (Basic, OAuth 1.0a, app links).
  - Requires additional configuration for external tool access (proxy, TLS, firewall rules).

<Callout type="info">
Feature parity between Cloud and self-hosted can vary. Validate API availability and required scopes for your Confluence version before integrating.
</Callout>

**Checklist when choosing deployment type:**
- Confirm auth method supported by your Confluence instance.
- Verify API surface and endpoints available in your Confluence version.
- Plan for network access (IP allowlists, VPN, reverse proxy) for self-hosted instances.

**Enterprise support considerations**

- Enterprise customers should coordinate with their Atlassian account team for support on Cloud tenant or Data Center issues.
- For self-hosted (Server/Data Center), coordinate with your internal infrastructure and security teams for firewall, TLS, and proxy configuration.

**Configuration notes**

- **Base URL**: For self-hosted instances set the tool's base URL to your Confluence base (example: `https://confluence.example.com`).
- **OAuth / API credentials**: Configure OAuth client ID/secret or API tokens in a secure secret store. Ensure client callback URLs match exactly.
- **Required scopes / permissions**:
  - Scopes for reading content and metadata (pages, spaces).
  - Scopes for creating/updating content and attachments if write operations are needed.
  - Scopes for comments and permissions management where applicable.
- **Network configuration**:
  - Allow outbound requests to Atlassian OAuth endpoints for Cloud.
  - For self-hosted, permit inbound requests from the tool or set up a secure reverse proxy.

<Callout type="warning">
Installing app links or configuring OAuth on Confluence requires Confluence admin permissions. Plan for an admin to perform initial setup and consent.
</Callout>

<Callout type="info">
Store credentials in a secrets manager and rotate them according to your security policy. Do not embed credentials in code or config files.
</Callout>

Permission behavior and limitations to note when integrating with Confluence:

- **Permission model**
  - API access follows Confluence user permissions. The integration can only read or modify content that the authenticated user/app has permission to access.
  - Space-level and page-level restrictions will prevent access to restricted content.
- **Common permission scopes needed**
  - Read spaces and pages
  - Read attachments
  - Create/update pages and attachments (if writing is required)
  - Add comments (if comment functionality is used)
- **Limitations**
  - Restricted pages and content are not accessible via the API unless the authenticated identity has explicit access.
  - Rate limits differ between Cloud and self-hosted; Cloud enforces Atlassian rate limitsimplement retry/backoff.
  - Large attachments or pages may be subject to size limits or timeouts; design upload and retrieval logic accordingly.
  - Impersonation is not generally supported; actions are performed as the granted OAuth user or service account.

<Callout type="info">
Where possible, use a dedicated service account with the minimal required scopes for automated integrations. For actions requiring user context, use OAuth flows that prompt the user for consent.
</Callout>
**Note**: For self-hosted Confluence, ensure the API base path and context (e.g., `/wiki/rest/api`) match your instance configuration. Mismatched paths are a common cause of integration failures.

- **Important**: Do not expose `App Secret` or other sensitive credentials in client-side code or public repositories.

## Auth

<Callout type="warning">
**Keep your Stripe secret key secure.** Do not commit `STRIPE_SECRET_KEY` to source control  use environment variables or a secrets manager.
</Callout>

**Required secret:**
- `STRIPE_SECRET_KEY`: Your Stripe API key.

At this time, Arcade does not offer a default Twitch Auth Provider. To use
  Twitch auth, you must create a custom Auth Provider with your own Twitch OAuth
  2.0 credentials as described below.

## Configuring Twitch auth

<Callout type="warning">
Twitch requires that you have **two-factor authentication** enabled for your account. Enable it in your [account security settings](https://www.twitch.tv/settings/security).
</Callout>

- Create a Twitch Application in the [Twitch App Console](https://dev.twitch.tv/console/apps).
- Set the OAuth Redirect URL to the redirect URL generated by Arcade (see below).
- Select your Application category.
- Choose the **Confidential** Client Type.
- Copy the App key (`Client ID`) and App secret (`Client Secret`)  you'll need these to configure Arcade.

<Callout type="info">
After creating the app, add it to the Arcade Dashboard:
- Navigate to the OAuth section of the Arcade Dashboard and click **Add OAuth Provider**.
- Select **Twitch** as the provider.
- Choose a unique **ID** and optional **Description**.
- Enter your **Client ID** and **Client Secret**.
- Note the **Redirect URL** generated by Arcade and set it as your Twitch app's OAuth Redirect URL.
- Click **Save**.

Arcade will automatically use this Twitch OAuth provider when you use tools that require Twitch auth with your Arcade account credentials.
</Callout>

## Using Twitch auth in app code

Use the Twitch auth provider in your agents and AI apps to obtain a user-scoped token for the Twitch API. See [authorizing agents with Arcade](/get-started/about-arcade) to understand the authorization flow.

- Start the authorization process for a user to obtain a token.
- Complete the browser-based authorization challenge when prompted.
- Wait for the authorization to complete and then retrieve the user token to call the Twitch API with the appropriate scopes.

<Callout type="info">
Ensure you request only the minimum scopes needed (for example, `channel:manage:polls`) and document which scopes your app requires.
</Callout>
documentationChunks.header: ## Using Twitch auth in app code

documentationChunks.content:
## Secrets

<Callout type="warning">
This MCP Server requires the `ZOHO_SERVER_URL` secret to be configured. Learn how to [configure secrets](/guides/create-tools/tool-basics/create-tool-secrets).
</Callout>

The Zoho Server URL is the base URL for your Zoho account's data center. Zoho operates in multiple data centers; you must use the correct URL for your account.

- US: `https://books.zoho.com`
- EU: `https://books.zoho.eu`
- India: `https://books.zoho.in`
- Australia: `https://books.zoho.com.au`
- China: `https://books.zoho.com.cn`

To determine which data center your account uses:
- Log in to your Zoho Books account
- Check the domain in your browser's address bar (for example, `.com`, `.eu`, `.in`, `.com.au`, or `.com.cn`)
- The domain indicates your data center and thus the correct `ZOHO_SERVER_URL`

Use the server URL as the base for all API requests.

The ZohoBooksApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-zoho` to connect to users' Zoho Books accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you must configure the `arcade-zoho` auth provider. Learn how to configure the Zoho auth provider in the [Zoho auth provider documentation](/references/auth-providers/zoho).

<Callout type="warning">
All tools in this toolset require the following secret: `GIT_SERVER_URL`.
</Callout>

The `GIT_SERVER_URL` secret specifies the GitHub server URL. Use `https://api.github.com` for regular GitHub.com accounts, or your GitHub Enterprise server URL (e.g., `https://github.your-company.com/api/v3`) for GitHub Enterprise deployments.

- Learn how to [configure secrets](/guides/create-tools/tool-basics/create-tool-secrets).

<Callout type="info">
The GithubApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-github` to connect to users' GithubApi accounts. Configure the `arcade-github` auth provider to allow the MCP Server to access user accounts.
</Callout>

For detailed information on configuring the GitHub OAuth provider with Arcade, see the [GitHub Auth Provider documentation](/references/auth-providers/github).

<Callout type="warning" title="Private OAuth app requirement">
The `projects:read` scope is **ONLY available in private Figma OAuth apps**. This scope is required for the navigation tools (`GetTeamProjects` and `GetProjectFiles`). 
If you need these navigation tools, you must create a private OAuth app through your Figma organization settings. All other tools work with public OAuth apps.
</Callout>

<Callout type="warning">
This MCP Server requires the `ZOHO_SERVER_URL` secret to be configured. Learn how to [configure secrets](/guides/create-tools/tool-basics/create-tool-secrets).
</Callout>

The Zoho Server URL is the base URL for your Zoho account's data center. Zoho operates in multiple data centers around the world, and you must use the correct URL for your account.

Data center server URLs:

- US: `https://creator.zoho.com`
- EU: `https://creator.zoho.eu`
- India: `https://creator.zoho.in`
- Australia: `https://creator.zoho.com.au`
- China: `https://creator.zoho.com.cn`

To determine which data center your account uses:

- Log in to your Zoho Creator account
- Check the domain in your browser's address bar (the domain suffix like `.com`, `.eu`, `.in`, `.com.au`, or `.com.cn` indicates the data center)
- Use the corresponding server URL from the list above

The server URL is used as the base for all API requests. Ensure the correct value is set in the `ZOHO_SERVER_URL` secret.

The ZohoCreatorApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-zoho` to connect to users' Zoho Creator accounts. You must configure the `arcade-zoho` auth provider.

Learn how to configure the Zoho auth provider in the [Zoho auth provider documentation](/references/auth-providers/zoho).

The Arcade E2B MCP Server uses [E2B](https://e2b.dev/) to run code in a sandboxed environment.

<Callout type="info">
**Global Environment Variables:**
- `E2B_API_KEY`: Your [E2B](https://e2b.dev/) API key.
</Callout>

**Note:** Provision the `E2B_API_KEY` in the runtime environment (for example, in your deployment or container secrets) before starting the service so the sandboxed execution can authenticate with E2B.

**Critical**: This MCP Server is built for **GitHub Apps**, not OAuth Apps.
  
  You **must** create a GitHub App (not an OAuth App) to use this server properly. 
  
   [Complete GitHub App Setup Guide](/references/auth-providers/github)
**Configuration Required**: All tools require secrets to be configured in Arcade Dashboard. See [Secrets Setup](#secrets-setup) below.

## GitHub Enterprise Support

<Callout type="info">
  This MCP Server fully supports **GitHub Enterprise Server 2.22+**
</Callout>

**Default Configuration:**
- If no `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` is configured, the default is `https://api.github.com` (GitHub.com)
- All tools work with GitHub.com out of the box

**For GitHub Enterprise Server:**

1. Create your GitHub App on your Enterprise instance (not github.com)
2. Configure the `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` secret in Arcade Dashboard (see [Secrets Setup](#secrets-setup) below)
3. Use your Enterprise server's API endpoint

**Example Enterprise Server URLs:**
- `https://github.yourcompany.com/api/v3`
- `https://enterprise.yourorg.com/api/v3`
- `https://git.company.internal/api/v3`

<Callout>
  **Note**: GitHub Enterprise Server uses the `/api/v3` path after the hostname. GitHub.com uses `https://api.github.com` (no `/api/v3` suffix).
</Callout>

---

## Configuration & Setup

### Authentication

<Callout type="warning">
  **Critical**: This MCP Server uses **GitHub Apps** authentication, not OAuth Apps.
  
  You **must** create a GitHub App to use this server. OAuth Apps are not supported.
</Callout>

The Arcade GitHub MCP Server uses the [GitHub auth provider](/references/auth-providers/github) to connect to users' GitHub accounts.

**For Arcade Cloud:**
- No configuration needed
- Your users will see `Arcade` as the requesting application
- All tools work out of the box

**For Self-Hosted:**
- You must [create your own GitHub App](/references/auth-providers/github#creating-a-github-app)
- [Configure the GitHub auth provider](/references/auth-providers/github#configuring-github-auth-in-arcade) with your app credentials
- Your users will see your application name

<Callout type="info">
  **New to GitHub Apps?** Read [Why Arcade Uses GitHub Apps](/references/auth-providers/github#why-arcade-uses-github-apps-not-oauth-apps) 
  to understand the security and compliance benefits.
</Callout>

### Secrets Setup

All tools require secrets to be configured in Arcade Dashboard.

**Steps:**

1. Go to [Arcade Dashboard](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard)
2. Navigate to **Secrets** in the left sidebar
3. Click **Add Secret**
4. Add the following secrets:

- **Secret Name**: `GITHUB_SERVER_URL`; **Value**: `https://api.github.com` (default for GitHub.com); **Required For**: All tools
- **Secret Name**: `GITHUB_CLASSIC_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN`; **Value**: Classic PAT with `notifications` scope; **Required For**: Notifications tools only


<Callout type="info">
  **Default**: If `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` is not configured, it defaults to `https://api.github.com` (GitHub.com)
  
  **GitHub Enterprise Users**: Set `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` to your Enterprise server's API endpoint (e.g., `https://github.yourcompany.com/api/v3`). Note that Enterprise uses `/api/v3` path. See [GitHub Enterprise Support](#github-enterprise-support) for details.
</Callout>

<Callout type="warning">
  **For Notifications Tools**: Create a classic Personal Access Token at [github.com/settings/tokens](https://github.com/settings/tokens) with only the `notifications` scope checked. GitHub Apps cannot access the notifications API.
</Callout>

---

## GitHub App Permissions Summary

When creating your GitHub App, grant the specific permissions below. This is a quick reference of which permissions are commonly required for repository, organization, and user-level actions.

<Callout type="info">
**Note:** `Metadata` read permission is automatically granted to GitHub Apps.
</Callout>

### Repository Permissions

- **Contents**  Read: All repository and pull request tools, getting file contents
- **Contents**  Write: Creating/updating files, creating branches, merging PRs
- **Issues**  Read & Write: Issue management, PR assignments, managing labels (issues)
- **Pull requests**  Read & Write: Pull request management, reviews, managing labels (pull requests)
- **Metadata**  Read: All tools (automatically granted)
- **Statuses**  Read: `CheckPullRequestMergeStatus`

### Organization Permissions

- **Members**  Read: Projects, collaborators, org repos, user search
- **Projects**  Read & Write: Projects V2 tools

### User Permissions

- **Read user profile**  Read: User-context tools, review workload
- **Act on behalf of user**  Enabled: `SetStarred` (starring repositories)

### Tools by Permission Requirements

**Basic Repository Access** (Contents Read + Metadata)
- `GetRepository`
- `CountStargazers`
- `ListStargazers`
- `ListRepositoryActivities`
- `GetFileContents`

**Repository Write** (Contents Write + Metadata)
- `CreateBranch`
- `CreateOrUpdateFile`
- `UpdateFileLines`

**Issue Management** (Contents Read + Issues + Metadata)
- `CreateIssue`
- `UpdateIssue`
- `GetIssue`
- `ListIssues`
- `CreateIssueComment`
- `ListRepositoryLabels`
- `ManageLabels` (for issues)

**Pull Request Read** (Contents + Pull requests Read + Metadata)
- `ListPullRequests`
- `GetPullRequest`
- `ListPullRequestCommits`
- `ListReviewCommentsOnPullRequest`
- `CheckPullRequestMergeStatus` (+ Statuses)

**Pull Request Write** (Contents Read + Pull requests Write + Metadata)
- `UpdatePullRequest`
- `CreatePullRequest`
- `SubmitPullRequestReview`
- `ManagePullRequest`
- `ManagePullRequestReviewers`
- `CreateReviewComment`
- `CreateReplyForReviewComment`
- `ResolveReviewThread`
- `ManageLabels` (for pull requests)
- `MergePullRequest` (+ Contents Write)

**Organization Tools** (Contents + Metadata + Members)
- `ListOrgRepositories`
- `SearchMyRepos`
- `ListRepositoryCollaborators`
- `AssignPullRequestUser` (+ Issues Write)

**Projects V2** (Contents + Metadata + Projects + Members)
- `ListProjects`
- `ListProjectItems`
- `SearchProjectItem`
- `ListProjectFields`
- `UpdateProjectItem` (Projects Write)

**User Context** (Contents + Metadata + Read user profile)
- `WhoAmI` (+ Members)
- `GetUserRecentActivity`
- `GetUserOpenItems`
- `GetReviewWorkload` (+ Pull requests Read)

** Special: Notifications** (Requires Classic PAT)
- `GetNotificationSummary`
- `ListNotifications`

<Callout type="warning">
**Warning:** GitHub Apps cannot access the Notifications API. Access to notifications requires a classic Personal Access Token with the `notifications` scope.
</Callout>

This integration requires the following secrets: `POSTHOG_SERVER_URL`, `POSTHOG_PERSONAL_API_KEY` (learn how to [configure secrets](/guides/create-tools/tool-basics/create-tool-secrets)).

<Callout type="info">
This supports both PostHog Cloud and self-hosted deployments.
</Callout>

### Getting Your PostHog Server URL

- The server URL depends on your PostHog deployment:
  - **PostHog Cloud (US Region)**: `https://us.posthog.com`
  - **PostHog Cloud (EU Region)**: `https://eu.posthog.com`
  - **Self-Hosted**: Use your instance's base URL (for example, `https://analytics.yourdomain.com`)
- You can verify your server URL by checking your PostHog account settings or the URL you use to access PostHog.

### Getting Your Personal API Key

- Log in to your PostHog account
- Click your avatar in the bottom-left corner
- Select the gear icon to open "Account settings"
- Navigate to the "Personal API Keys" section
- Click "+ Create a personal API key"
- Provide a descriptive label for the key
- Select the necessary scopes (choose only the scopes required for your use case)
- Click "Create key"
- **Copy and securely store the key immediately**  it will not be shown again

<Callout type="warning">
Keep the personal API key secret and grant only the minimal scopes required for your use case.
</Callout>

For more details on authentication and API usage, refer to the [PostHog API documentation](https://posthog.com/docs/api).

Once you have both values, configure them as secrets in your environment or tool configuration. Learn more about [configuring secrets](/guides/create-tools/tool-basics/create-tool-secrets).

<Callout type="info">
**Required environment variables:** `DATADOG_API_KEY`, `DATADOG_APPLICATION_KEY`, `DATADOG_BASE_URL`
</Callout>

The Arcade Datadog API MCP Server requires three environment variables to authenticate with the [Datadog API](https://docs.datadoghq.com/api/latest/):

- `DATADOG_API_KEY`
- `DATADOG_APPLICATION_KEY`
- `DATADOG_BASE_URL`

**How to obtain your credentials:**

- Log in to your [Datadog dashboard](https://app.datadoghq.com/).
- Navigate to **Organization Settings** (click your profile icon in the bottom left).
- Go to **API Keys** and create a new key (provide a name and click **Create Key**).
- Go to **Application Keys** and create a new key (provide a name and click **Create Key**).
- Determine your **Base URL** based on your Datadog site (check the URL in your browser):
  - US1: `api.datadoghq.com`
  - US3: `api.us3.datadoghq.com`
  - US5: `api.us5.datadoghq.com`
  - EU1: `api.datadoghq.eu`
  - AP1: `api.ap1.datadoghq.com`
  - GOV: `api.ddog-gov.com`

<Callout type="warning">
**Warning:** Keep `DATADOG_API_KEY` and `DATADOG_APPLICATION_KEY` secret. Do not commit these values to source control or expose them in logs.
</Callout>

For more details, see the [Datadog API and Application Keys documentation](https://docs.datadoghq.com/account_management/api-app-keys/).

This MCP Server requires the `ARCADE_API_KEY` secret to be configured. Without it, requests to the Arcade Engine will fail.
</Callout>

**Getting your Arcade API Key**

- To use the Arcade Engine API MCP Server, you need an Arcade API key. This key authenticates your requests to the Arcade Engine.
- Learn how to create and manage your Arcade API keys in the [API Keys documentation](/get-started/setup/api-keys).
- Configure the `ARCADE_API_KEY` secret in your MCP Server settings as described in the [configure secrets](/guides/create-tools/tool-basics/create-tool-secrets) guide.

<Callout type="info">
Ensure the secret name is exactly `ARCADE_API_KEY` and that the value is kept secure. Rotate keys regularly and update the MCP secret when keys are replaced.

The Arcade Web MCP Server uses [Firecrawl](https://www.firecrawl.dev/) to scrape, crawl, and map websites.

**Global Environment Variables:**
- `FIRECRAWL_API_KEY`: Your [Firecrawl](https://www.firecrawl.dev/) API key.

<Callout type="warning">
**Keep the API key secret**  do not commit `FIRECRAWL_API_KEY` to source control or expose it in client-side code.
</Callout>

<Callout type="info">
Check [Firecrawl](https://www.firecrawl.dev/) for available deployment and enterprise options (cloud, self-hosted, enterprise plans) and follow their configuration guides for API access.
</Callout>

## Secrets

This integration requires the following secrets:

- `BRIGHTDATA_API_KEY`
- `BRIGHTDATA_ZONE`

<Callout type="info">
This integration uses Bright Data to access proxy networks and web scraping infrastructure.
</Callout>

### Auth

**Global Environment Variables:**

- `BRIGHTDATA_API_KEY`: Your Bright Data API key. You can generate this from your [Bright Data dashboard](https://brightdata.com/cp/zones) under Account Settings  API Access.

- `BRIGHTDATA_ZONE`: Your Bright Data zone name (for example, `residential_proxy1`). This is the zone identifier you created in your Bright Data dashboard under Proxies & Scraping Infrastructure  Zones.

**How to get your credentials:**

1. **API Key**: Navigate to your [Bright Data Control Panel](https://brightdata.com/cp)  Settings  API Access  Generate API Token
2. **Zone**: Go to the Zones section in your dashboard and locate your zone name. The zone username is typically in the format `brd-customer-{customer_id}-zone-{zone_name}`.

<Callout type="warning">
Keep your `BRIGHTDATA_API_KEY` secret. Do not commit it to source control or expose it in client-side code.
</Callout>

For more details, see the [Bright Data API Documentation](https://docs.brightdata.com/api-reference).

## Authentication

The Arcade Weaviate API MCP Server requires two environment variables to authenticate with your Weaviate instance:

- `WEAVIATE_API_KEY`
- `WEAVIATE_SERVER_URL`

**How to obtain your credentials:**

- 1. Log in to your [Weaviate Console](https://console.weaviate.cloud/)
- 2. Select your Weaviate cluster
- 3. Navigate to **Details** or **API Keys** section
- 4. Click **Create API Key** or use an existing key
- 5. Copy your **API Key**
- 6. Copy your **Cluster URL** (this is your server URL and must include `https://`)

<Callout type="info">
The `WEAVIATE_SERVER_URL` must include the full URL with the `https://` protocol (for example, `https://your-cluster.weaviate.network`).
</Callout>

For more details, see the [Weaviate Authentication documentation](https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/configuration/authentication).

<Callout type="warning" title="Classic PagerDuty OAuth">
  Arcade supports Classic PagerDuty apps. Select **read-only** access; all tools
  in this MCP Server only read data. (Use read/write only if you add custom
  write tools.) See [PagerDuty OAuth
  functionality](https://developer.pagerduty.com/docs/oauth-functionality).
</Callout>

Configure PagerDuty OAuth in the [PagerDuty auth
  provider](/references/auth-providers/pagerduty) before using these tools.

**PagerDuty requires OAuth2.** Configure the PagerDuty auth provider and request the scopes shown above per tool. Tokens are passed as Bearer auth.

<Callout type="info">
Configure the PagerDuty auth provider and request the required scopes for each tool. Do not embed tokens in code or store them in plaintext.
</Callout>

See PagerDuty auth docs: [PagerDuty API Authentication](https://developer.pagerduty.com/docs/ZG9jOjExMDI5NTYz-authentication).

This MCP Sever is meant to be an example of how to build a MCP Sever for a
  database, and is not intended to be used in production - you won't find it
  listed in the Arcade dashboard or APIs. For production use, we recommend
  forking this repository and building your own MCP Sever with use-case specific
  tools.

## Key Features

ClickHouse integration supports the following features:

- **Schema discovery**: Automatically discover available database schemas
- **Table exploration**: Find all tables within a specific schema
- **Schema inspection**: Get detailed column information including data types, primary keys, and indexes
- **Safe query execution**: Execute `SELECT` queries with built-in safety measures
- **Connection pooling**: Reuse database connections efficiently
- **Read-only access**: Enforce read-only access to prevent data modification
- **Row limits**: Automatically limit query results to prevent overwhelming responses

## Usage Workflow

For optimal results, follow this workflow when using the ClickHouse integration:

- **Discover Schemas**: Use `discover_schemas` to see available schemas
- **Discover Tables**: Use `discover_tables` with your target schema
- **Get Table Schema**: Use `get_table_schema` for each table you plan to query
- **Execute Query**: Use `execute_select_query` with the schema information

This workflow ensures the agent has complete information about the database structure before attempting queries, reducing errors and improving query performance.

## Intercom API Subdomain

<Callout type="warning">
The IntercomApi MCP Server requires setting the `INTERCOM_API_SUBDOMAIN` secret in the Arcade Dashboard.
</Callout>

- For the United States servers, set `INTERCOM_API_SUBDOMAIN` to `api`
- For the European servers, set `INTERCOM_API_SUBDOMAIN` to `api.eu`
- For the Australian servers, set `INTERCOM_API_SUBDOMAIN` to `api.au`

## Auth

The IntercomApi MCP Server uses the Auth Provider with id `arcade-intercom` to connect to users' IntercomApi accounts. In order to use the MCP Server, you will need to configure the `arcade-intercom` auth provider.

<Callout type="info">
Configure the `arcade-intercom` auth provider in the Arcade Dashboard before enabling the IntercomApi MCP Server.
</Callout>

This MCP Sever is meant to be an example of how to build a MCP Sever for a

  listed in the Arcade dashboard or APIs. For production use, we recommend
  forking this repository and building your own MCP Sever with use-case specific
  tools.

## Key Features

<Callout type="info">
This MCP Server demonstrates important concepts for LLM-powered database interactions.
</Callout>

- **Schema Discovery**: Automatically discover available database schemas
- **Table Exploration**: Find all tables within a specific schema
- **Schema Inspection**: Get detailed column information including data types, primary keys, and indexes
- **Safe Query Execution**: Execute SELECT queries with built-in safety measures
- **Connection Pooling**: Reuse database connections efficiently
- **Read-Only Access**: Enforce read-only access to prevent data modification
- **Row Limits**: Automatically limit query results to prevent overwhelming responses

## Usage Workflow

For optimal results, follow this workflow when using the Postgres MCP Server:

- **Discover Schemas**: Use `discover_schemas` to see available schemas
- **Discover Tables**: Use `discover_tables` with your target schema
- **Get Table Schema**: Use `get_table_schema` for each table you plan to query
- **Execute Query**: Use `execute_select_query` with the schema information

This workflow ensures your agent has complete information about the database structure before attempting queries, reducing errors and improving query performance.

<Callout type="warning" title="Admin token required">
  Pylon API tokens are admin-scoped and created in Pylon by an org admin. Store
  the token as `PYLON_API_TOKEN` in Arcade secrets. There is no user OAuth.
</Callout>

Pylon uses Bearer tokens created by an org admin. There is **no OAuth flow**. Generate an API token in the Pylon dashboard and store it as the secret `PYLON_API_TOKEN` in Arcade. All tools require this secret.

<Callout type="warning">
**Admin-only token**

Pylon tokens are generated by admins in the Pylon UI and grant org-level access. Rotate tokens regularly and scope storage to your Arcade projects secrets.
</Callout>

Refer to Pylons authentication docs: [Pylon API Authentication](https://docs.usepylon.com/pylon-docs/developer/api/authentication).

This MCP Sever is meant to be an example of how to build a MCP Sever for a
  database, and is not intended to be used in production - you won't find it
  listed in the Arcade dashboard or APIs. For production use, we recommend
  forking this repository and building your own MCP Sever with use-case specific
  tools.

## Key Features

This MCP Server demonstrates several important concepts for LLM-powered database interactions:

- **Database Discovery**: Automatically discover available databases in the MongoDB instance
- **Collection Exploration**: Find all collections within a specific database
- **Schema Inference**: Sample documents to infer schema structure and data types
- **Safe Query Execution**: Execute find queries with built-in safety measures
- **Aggregation Support**: Run complex aggregation pipelines for data analysis
- **Document Counting**: Count documents matching specific criteria
- **Connection Pooling**: Reuse database connections efficiently
- **Read-Only Access**: Enforce read-only access to prevent data modification
- **Result Limits**: Automatically limit query results to prevent overwhelming responses

## Usage Workflow

For optimal results, follow this workflow when using the MongoDB MCP Server:

- **Discover Databases**: Use `discover_databases` to see available databases
- **Discover Collections**: Use `discover_collections` with your target database
- **Get Collection Schema**: Use `get_collection_schema` for each collection you plan to query
- **Execute Queries**: Use `find_documents`, `count_documents`, or `aggregate_documents` with the schema information

This workflow ensures your agent has complete information about the database structure before attempting queries, reducing errors and improving query performance.
